title: Defining Zone 2 Exercise
content: Peter and Bob take a deep dive into zone 2 training. They begin with a detailed definition of zone 2 and continue by discussing the importance of adding it to your exercise regimen.

title: Programming Zone 2 Training
content: Peter and Bob discuss how to program zone 2 training, including intensity, frequency, and duration, and metrics for tracking improvement. They also talk about the process of training a deconditioned individual with zone 2: Dosage, frequency, and metrics to watch.

title: Training for Health vs. Performance
content: Peter and Bob discuss the importance of dedicating training time solely to zone 2 and the difference between training for health vs. performance.

title: Improving Mitochondrial Density and Function
content: Peter and Bob discuss how zone 2 training can improve mitochondrial density and function.

title: Metrics for Monitoring Fitness Levels
content: Peter and Bob discuss metrics to monitor improving fitness levels from zone 2 training.

title: Choosing Equipment for Aerobic Training
content: Peter and Bob compare the various equipment options for aerobic training, including rowing machine, treadmill, stairmaster, and more.

title: Magnesium Supplementation
content: Peter and Bob provide a detailed overview of all things related to magnesium supplementation, including Peter's personal protocol.

title: Engaging with Your Doctor
content: Peter and Bob provide advice for effectively engaging with your doctor in the pursuit of getting your questions answered and considerations for finding a physician that’s right for you.

title: Defining Zone 2 Exercise
content: Zone 2 is defined as your highest metabolic output/work that you can sustain while keeping your lactate level below two millimole per liter (mmol/L). Biochemically, what’s happening as you exercise (or do anything) is the process of respiration, the process of using substrate. We use glucose, we use fatty acids, we use oxygen, and we undergo a chemical process. The body has a choice whether to continue this process outside of the mitochondria where I make another by-product called lactate (which can generate a little bit more ATP); Or take that pyruvate and shuttle it into the mitochondria, and undergo a separate chemical pathway and a separate process called the Krebs cycle where you can make MANY more ATPs.

title: ATP Production Pathways
content: If you need to make ATP really quickly, you’ll take that former pathway and make lactate because you don’t need oxygen to do it—meaning you’re not limited by the amount of oxygen that is being taken up by the muscle. If you have more time on your hands, you’ll take the latter pathway—meaning you will utilize oxygen and actually take that substrate into the mitochondria, and you will be able to make tons of ATP.

title: Differentiation Between Individuals
content: What differentiates the highly trained/metabolically fit from the untrained/metabolically unfit…is that ability to, under a greater and greater array of metabolic demands, make that input of substrate into the mitochondria. Mitochondrial health then can be somewhat estimated and proxied by the ability a person has to do this. One of the most valuable ways to do this is to measure lactate levels.

title: Lactate Levels at Rest and During Exercise
content: A healthy person when they’re sitting there at rest has a lactate level of about 1.0 mmol/L. Basic activities of daily living (walking, standing, eating) shouldn’t at all be pushing you to generate higher levels of lactate to the point that you accumulating lactate. At some point, you’re going to have to start generating lactate (even the fittest person ever).

title: Zone 2 Exercise
content: The fitter a person is, the healthier a person is, the more work they can do with less lactate. For a given individual, we use this metric of zone 2 as a place to understand how metabolically healthy they are; how good their mitochondria are; and how much work can be done while keeping your lactate about 1.7 to 2.0 mmol/L. You can think of zone 2 as your “all day pace”.

title: Effective Ways to Engage in Zone 2 Exercise
content: Machines for doing zone 2 exercise: Bicycle (Peter’s preference), Treadmill (2nd best option), Rowing machine (will work for efficient rowers but Peter says doing zone 5 on a rower is best), Elliptical (Peter’s least favorite but can be done). When doing zone 2, you want a machine where it’s very easy to reproducibly produce the same output.

title: Bike Bicycle
content: Peter sets his road bike on a device called a Wahoo KICKR which is hooked up to a computer where you tell it the numbers of Watts you want and it sets the resistance for you. Peter loves this way to doing zone 2 because it takes all the thinking out of it, you can just “tune out” and know you’re staying in zone 2.

title: Treadmills
content: For most people, running gets them out of zone two a little too quickly. With patients, Peter prefers them to do brisk walking on an incline. You have to figure out which incline and speed will keep you, personally, in zone 2, but once you know then you can set it and go. He starts people between 10 and 15 degrees incline and 2.5-3.0 mph on the speed.

title: Rowing Machine
content: Peter is not fond of the rowing machine for zone 2. He prefers to use the rowing machine for zone 5. However, someone who is an efficient rower like Beth Lewis (previous podcast guest) can get a zone 2 work out on the rowing machine.

title: Elliptical
content: Peter is not hugely fond of ellipticals for zone 2 because it’s hard to stay in the proper zone. And it’s really important that you’re not vacillating in and out of “zone 2”.

title: Training a deconditioned/metabolically ill individual
content: Someone who is very metabolically ill may be already at 2 mmol of lactate at rest. So right after they jump on the bike their lactate starts to shoot up. So it becomes quite the challenge to get that person to sustain 45 minutes (recommended zone 2 dose). Essentially, they are immediately getting out of mitochondrial oxidation and they’re burning nearly all glucose instead of fat (which is not the purpose of dedicated zone 2 exercise). How would Peter go about training that person? Let’s say you take a person who’s resting lactate is 1.5 to 2.0 mmol (NOTE: Metformin will raise your resting lactate by the way). This persons mitochondria probably does not work that well. You put that person on a bike at 100 watts, their lactate could easily be 5.0 mmol in 20 minutes. What do we do with that person? How do we get that person in shape? Short answer is you just accept the fact that in the short term their lactate is going to blow past 2.0 (meaning their not in zone 2). So in the beginning, Peter would rely what’s called rate of perceived exertion (RPE). Combing that metric with heart rate and lactate and you can start to triangulate on zone 2. But the really metabolically inflexible person… It’s really an art to it sometimes you have to just rely more on RPE.

title: Exercise for metabolically unhealthy people
content: These people generally will start to show results very quickly. Ideally like to have these people exercising up to three hours a week. Peter is pushing our patients to do three or four sessions weekly no shorter than 45 minutes per session.

title: Training for a marathon
content: Eliud Kipchoge broke the world record for a marathon (26.2) miles at 2:01:39. The incredible part about this record is that Kipchoge would have had his lactate below two millimole that entire time except for maybe the last 15 minutes or so.

title: Zone 2 training
content: Even the elite athletes spend about 70% of their time in zone 2. Peter recommends each session to be at least 45 minutes. Peter’s regimen might look like this: A session of zone 2 only, A session of zone 5 only, A HIIT session (which is sort of neuromuscular) separately.

title: Fasted state training
content: Peter likes to go into his zone 2 sessions in a fasted state. The reason is that he wants maximum substrate—meaning as much fatty acid and glucose available for his muscles. If you can do these [zone 2 sessions] fasted, you’re stressing the system in a good way.

title: Improving mitochondrial density and function
content: A benefit of zone 2 training is increasing mitochondrial density & function. It’s hard to know without more extensive studies with biopsies, says Peter.

title: Effect of single limb exercise on non-working muscles
content: Peter’s intuition is that it probably wouldn’t have much of an effect on non-working muscles. Bob suspects that single leg zone 2 training might result in some type of adaptations that would be beneficial such as preservation (rather than growth) in skeletal muscle in the non-exercised limb.

title: Metrics to monitor improving fitness levels from zone 2 training
content: Zone 2 exercise done properly should improve mitochondrial function, fat utilization, and lactate clearance. FTP is defined as the maximum power you can sustain for one hour. With zone 2 done properly, you should see improving fat oxidation, improving lactate clearance, and therefore improved mitochondrial function. And with those improvements, you should technically be able to increase your output while staying in your zone 2.

title: Advice for choosing a bicycle for zone 2 exercise at home
content: A real street bike hooked to a device to make it “stationary” (Peter’s preference). In Peter’s case, he prefers using a real bicycle (brand Pinarello) and strapping it into a Wahoo KICKR. Wahoo KICKR makes a device called the Wahoo KICKR that you set your bike onto so you’re riding your street bike on a device. A stationary bicycle is designed to be ridden in a stationary fashion indoors.

title: Best stationary bike: Keiser brand
content: If you’re buying a stationary bike from the standpoint of form factor, Peter says the Keiser bikes are hands down the best

title: Gadgets and software for cycling
content: Bob uses a street bike strapped to a Wahoo KICKR, a gadget called Climb which can change the incline of the ride, and a software called Sufferfest. Peter recommends Wahoo's Headwind fan for cooling.

title: Comparing aerobic training equipment
content: Peter recommends rowing for its full-body workout, but warns that proper form is crucial to avoid injury. Walking on a treadmill at an incline or cycling is easier to maintain zone 2 than walking on flat ground or jogging. Peter loves the StairMaster for zone 2 and 5.

title: Back pain and exercise
content: Peter had a botched back surgery in 2000 that left him with low stability in his lower back. He recommends non-surgical intervention and doing more homework on the right surgeon before undergoing surgery.

title: Peter's Experience with Back Pain
content: Peter has had multiple surgeries on his back, including a discectomy on the wrong side and complications after a discectomy on the other side. He has had to have more and more bone removed over time, which has affected the stability of his joints. Peter's focus is now on reducing the probability of chronic pain and injury as he ages. He believes that being active and mobile can help decrease back pain.

title: The Importance of Magnesium
content: Magnesium is a super important mineral that is found in bones and soft tissues. It is essential for the functions of many enzyme systems and for neuromuscular transmission. Magnesium depletion is not uncommon, and it is needed for muscle and nerve function. Magnesium has important interrelationships with other cations like calcium, potassium, and phosphorus. There are two broad categories of magnesium: poorly absorbed and efficiently absorbed. Magnesium citrate or magnesium oxide are poorly absorbed forms of magnesium that can help with bowel function.

title: Peter's Magnesium Protocol
content: Peter takes 3 forms of magnesium: oxide, chloride (Slow Mag), and L-threonate (Magtein). When NOT fasting, he takes ~400-500 mg of oxide (morning), 2 tablets of Slow Mag (morning), and 2 capsules of Magtein (before bed). When fasting, he stops the oxide, takes a double dose of Slow Mag, and continues to take his Magtein before bed.

title: Advice for Engaging with and Questioning Your Doctor
content: Physicians are in a tough position—many doctors must see upwards of 6 patients an hour to maintain their practice which squeezes the time they have for answering questions from patients unrelated to the particular visit. Best practice: Send them an email before your appointment to give them a chance to reflect your questions, read up on it, and have their point of view ready. If you’re not getting an answer that you’re comfortable with from your doctor, you should go find another doctor.
